tossups.question: A joint Finnish-American team in this city has been examining a set of burnt papyri found in a Byzantine church. Dan Gibson's Quranic Geography argues that, instead of facing Jerusalem or Mecca, early qiblas faced this city. Josephus identifies Miriam's burial site with this city. Inscriptions found in a "monastery" in this city refer to its use in the cult of king Obodas I, an opponent of the Hasmoneans. Mount Hor, which lies outside this city, is believed to be where the (*) Tomb of Aaron is located. This city's Great Temple is connected to two cisterns, which each feed into subterranean canals. People would enter this Nabataean ("na-buh-TEE-in") capital city through a slot canyon known as the Siq, which ends at the entrance of its iconic "Treasury". For 10 points, name this ancient rock-cut city in Jordan.
tossups.answer: Petra [or al-Batra; or Raqmu; or Rekem]

tossups.question: A D major string quartet by this composer, whose nickname comes from the soaring melody on the E string in its first movement, was arranged into one of his 32 pieces for mechanical clock. This composer wrote solo piano, orchestral, and string quartet versions of a piece which consists of an Introduzione, seven sonata movements, and the conclusion "Il terremoto". Two of this man's piano trios are attributed to his student Ignaz Pleyel ("EEG-notz PLAY-ul"). He wrote the (*) "Lark" quartet as part of a set of six quartets for Johann Tost, as well as the Seven Last Words of Christ. A symphony by this composer begins with the soft theme (read slowly) "C-C-E-E-G-G-E" before presenting the Paukenschlag ("POW-ken-shlag"), a sudden fortissimo chord. For 10 points, name this "Father of the String Quartet" who composed the "Surprise" symphony.
tossups.answer: (Franz) Joseph Haydn

tossups.question: An early formulation of this author's notion of an "existential revolution" is found in the prison letters to his wife published in his magazine Expedition Edition. Echoing Karl Marx, this author wrote "a specter is haunting Eastern Europe" to begin an essay which describes a greengrocer who displays "workers of the world, unite" in his window. This author of Letters to Olga created a character who repeatedly shouts "Check!" at an event where he meets the "inaugurator" (*) Maxy and learns to speak in bureaucratic clichés. In that play by him, Mr. Kalabis is part of the Liquidation Office, which hosts the title celebration attended by Hugo Pludek. The essay The Power of the Powerless and the play The Garden Party are by, for 10 points, what author and first president of the Czech Republic?
tossups.answer: Vaclav Havel

tossups.question: In 2001, Samantha Power criticized speeches that this official wrote for Al Gore about the Rwandan genocide for lacking urgency regarding the event. This official, whose mother Lois was called the "Mother of the Pell Grant", briefly considered challenging Susan Collins for Senate in Maine in 2019. In the memoir Tough Love, this person remarks on scrutiny from conservative media over remarks about an American-made anti-Islamic video, which she claimed was the main motive for a (*) 2012 attack on the U.S. embassy in Benghazi. Before the selection of Kamala Harris, this former diplomat was rumored to be at the top of Joe Biden's shortlist for VP nominees. For 10 points, name this woman who, during the Obama administration, served as ambassador to the United Nations.
tossups.answer: Susan Rice [prompt on Rice]

tossups.question: In this technique, signal intensities can be measured in 6 different ways, such as "spatial average temporal average" or "spatial peak pulse peak". A device used in this technique contains a "backing layer" and a "matching layer" sandwiching a crystal of PZT. This technique is typically performed in the B-mode or "brightness mode", whose output is proportional to a certain analogue of electrical impedance. This technique can be combined with the Doppler effect to measure the velocity of (*) blood flow. Deformities like spina bifida and congenital heart defects can be diagnosed with this technique, which is usually performed between weeks 18 and 20 of pregnancy. Echocardiography is a specific form of, for 10 points, what medical imaging technique which uses high frequency acoustic waves?
tossups.answer: ultrasonography [or ultrasound imaging; accept echocardiography or echocardiogram before mention; prompt on sound imaging]

tossups.question: Excavations in this colony's town of Anhaica ("ahn-EYE-kah") revealed olive jars used by an expedition staying over the winter. Briton Hammond only recounts being given "boil'd corn" by his captors after being shipwrecked and kidnapped in this colony. James Moore led raids against the Apalachee ("ah-puh-LATCH-ee") in this colony during Queen Anne's War. This colony's Matanzas Inlet got its name after troops massacred (*) Huguenots at Fort Caroline near it. After being granted this colony by Charles V, Panfilo de Narváez ("pahn-FEE-lo day nahr-VAH-ez") led a failed expedition to colonize it. Apocryphally, while searching for the Fountain of Youth, Ponce de León ("pons day lay-OWN") discovered this colony and named it after a Spanish Easter festival. The first permanent European settlement in the present-day U.S was in, for 10 points, what colony's city of St. Augustine?
tossups.answer: Spanish Florida [or La Florida]

tossups.question: Two hadiths from the Sahih al-Bukhari describing a modified form of this practice in severe weather justified a recent Kuwaiti modification during the coronavirus pandemic. Uthman ordered that a version of this practice be done in markets, so many Sunnis do a specific instance of it twice. When this practice is performed (emphasize) before fajr, Sunnis add a phrase that calls a certain action "better than (*) sleep". This practice, often followed by a shorter instance of it called the iqama, was first done by the freed Ethiopian slave Bilal ibn Rabah. It begins by repeating the takbir and the shahada and is now typically performed with the aid of a loudspeaker five times per day. For 10 points, what practice, usually done by a muezzin from a minaret, announces that Muslims should perform salat?
tossups.answer: adhan [or azan; or call to prayer; accept descriptive equivalents, including ones with "salah" or "salat" in place of "prayer" before the end; do not accept or prompt on just "prayer", "salah", or "salat"]

tossups.question: At the last minute, the composer of this film's soundtrack lost his Academy Award nomination after it was learned that he adapted music from the film Fortunella. A wedding in this film features a clip of the aria "Non so più cosa son" from The Marriage of Figaro and a mazurka dance. A melodic English horn solo opens a "Pastorale" played in this film as a character visits his father in the hospital. This film's title sequence begins with a (*) trumpet playing a slow triple-meter dance composed by Nino Rota, who also published the song "Speak Softly, Now," which is called this film's "Love Theme". It begins with an iconic opening waltz and features the singing of "I Have but One Heart" by Johnny Fontane. For 10 points, name this Francis Ford Coppola film about the Corleone family.
tossups.answer: The Godfather

tossups.question: B.J. Bahnson used sterically-crowded mutants of horse liver ADH to "unmask" the effects of this phenomenon on the enzyme's activity. In hydrogen transfer reactions, this phenomenon can cause an anomalous enhancement to the kinetic isotope effect, an effect modeled by adding Bell's Q-factor to the Arrhenius equation. The read-heads of modern hard disk drives use a form of magnetoresistance dependent on this phenomenon. (*) Binnig and Rohrer invented a device that uses this phenomenon between a sample and a piezoelectric tip to achieve sub-nanometer resolution. In this phenomenon, the wavefunction exponentially decays in a narrow region where the energy is smaller than the potential. For 10 points, name this process in which a particle crosses a classically-forbidden potential barrier.
tossups.answer: quantum tunneling [prompt on kinetic isotope effect or KIE before "kinetic"]

tossups.question: This family's apartment is described as part of an "interfused mass of automatism" created by "hive-like conglomerations of cellular living-units". This family's son rebukes one criticism by saying "I didn't go to the moon, I went much further" before saying he followed in his "father's footsteps" by descending the fire escape for the last time. This family's mother misses a D.A.R. meeting to stop by Rubicam's business college to talk to a (*) typing instructor about her daughter's cold. That daughter in this family scolds her brother for failing to realize his colleague at the shoe factory is engaged. Its matriarch recounts a single afternoon in Blue Mountain when she received 17 gentleman callers. Tom, Laura, and Amanda are members of, for 10 points, what family from The Glass Menagerie?
tossups.answer: Wingfield family [prompt on a description of the family from The Glass Menagerie, before The Glass Menagerie is mentioned]

tossups.question: The equation of state for these objects can be classified as "soft" or "stiff" based on their polytropic index. These objects are thought to lie at the cores of the hypothetical Thorne-Zytkow objects. The internal structures of these objects are thought to form rod, slab, and bubble phases depending on density. In 2019, data from the Very Large Telescope confirmed that collisions between these objects can trigger the r-process, producing (*) strontium. Soft gamma repeaters are thought to be a subtype of these objects with a magnetic field above 1 billion Tesla. These objects form when a star between 10 and 25 solar masses undergoes a core-collapse supernova; lighter stars will instead produce white dwarfs. For 10 points, what stellar remnants are made from a neutral subatomic particle?
tossups.answer: neutron stars [prompt on pulsars or magnetars or stars]

tossups.question: In a novel by this author, a maid reveals that a dead body is in the Leroys' car while speaking to the man who hit her own car during a snowstorm. In another novel by this author, weekly flower deliveries to Lark House prompt suspicion that an old lady is meeting Ichimei Fukuda. In a third novel by this author, a man escapes Férula's prophecy that he will "die like a dog," as he dies in the arms of a woman whom he helped rescue from military prison when she was pregnant. This author of (*) In the Midst of Winter and The Japanese Lover wrote a novel in which Blanca ignores her father and has an affair with Pedro Tercero García. In that novel by her, a clairvoyant child goes mute for nine years after Rosa dies, before later marrying Esteban Trueba. For 10 points, name this author of The House of the Spirits.
tossups.answer: Isabel Allende

tossups.question: A book by Michael Maier consists of fifty discourses and fugues allegorizing this object as Atalanta fleeing. Allegorical illustrations describing this object make up the Mutus Liber. George Starkey described this object as being made of "sophic" substances in works he wrote under the name Eirenaeus Philalethes. This object forms in stages termed nigredo, albedo, and rubedo, denoting putrefaction, purification, and unification of (*) opposites. This object, also called the "tincture", is symbolized by a circle in a square in a triangle in a circle, showing the union of the four elements. This object is made from the prima materia, or "first matter", and its creation is the magnum opus. Nicolas Flamel legendarily used it to make the elixir of life. For 10 points, name this object sought by alchemists that could turn lead into gold.
tossups.answer: philosophers' stone [or lapis philosophorum; before mentioned, accept tincture]

tossups.question: So-called "China" examples of these people formed the nucleus of jingoistic societies of imperialist agitators such as the Aikokusha ("eye-koh-koo-sha"). After legally becoming one of these people, a man wrote the Dokkōdō, often called these people's "21 Rules of Life". A scheme of using "daytime lanterns" to distract Kira Yoshinaka was devised by a leader of several of these people named Ōishi Yoshio ("oh-ee-shee yoh-shee-oh") during the 18th century Akō incident. In modern Japan, salarymen are often referred to as these people if they are (*) unemployed. During his last four years of life, the philosopher Miyamoto Musashi was one of these people due to the death of the daimyo Hosokawa Tadatoshi. The name Chushingura ("choo-sheen-goo-rah") is given to tales regarding a vengeful group of 47 of these people. For 10 points, name these samurai without masters.
tossups.answer: ronin [accept China ronin; prompt on samurai before "samurai"]

tossups.question: A generating example of these functions must exist for any level set whose corresponding bundles satisfy Houthakker's axioms. By a representation theorem, one of these functions exists if certain properties obey the axioms of completeness, transitivity, continuity, and independence. If the ratio of the second derivative of one of these functions to its first derivative is negative, then the Arrow-Pratt measure is positive, implying (*) risk aversion. A common behavioral optimization problem finds the point where the value of one of these functions is highest, given a budget constraint for a consumer. These functions, which are typically ordinal in behavioral economics, have constant output along indifference curves. For 10 points, what functions measure an agent's benefit from a good or service?
tossups.answer: utility functions (The second clue refers to the Von Neumann-Morgenstern theorem.)

tossups.question: Warren Hirsch was inspired by this specific algorithm to conjecture an upper bound on the diameter of certain objects in D-dimensional Euclidean space. This was the first algorithm whose worst-case complexity was shown to be exponential time by the Klee-Minty cube. To prevent this algorithm from infinitely cycling, criteria like Bland's rule are used to pick an entering column for the basis. This algorithm uses (*) Phase I (one) and Phase II (two) problems to determine if the original problem has a solution. This algorithm creates a tableau by augmenting the system's matrix with slack variables, then uses pivot operations to tweak the objective function while moving around the vertices of the feasible region. George Dantzig developed, for 10 points, what algorithm to find optimal solutions to linear programming problems?
tossups.answer: Simplex algorithm [accept Dantzig's algorithm before "Dantzig"]

tossups.question: In this decade, the Duchess of Atholl organized a camp at Stoneham for refugees aboard the Habana. In this decade, citizens of Jarrow marched on Parliament to demand the construction of a steel factory. Sailors protesting pay cuts in the "Invergordon Mutiny" forced Great Britain to move off the gold standard in this decade. An organization whose logo was a white thunderbolt against a blue circle fought the (*) Battle of Cable Street in this decade. In this decade, the Stresa Front agreement reaffirmed the prior decade’s Locarno Treaties. After returning from the Munich Conference in this decade, a prime minister declared "Peace for Our Time." For 10 points, Neville Chamberlain failed to prevent Hitler from invading Poland at the end of what decade?
tossups.answer: 1930s [prompt on 30s]

tossups.question: A book titled for this adjective criticizes an "inflationary metaphysics" regarding statements about unobservable phenomena, and was written by Bas van Fraasen. Proponents of an epistemic ("eh-piss-TEH-mik") attitude described by this adjective often cite the rule of "inference to the best explanation" and Hilary Putnam's "no miracles" argument; that theory is called this sort of "realism". Another book contrasts the (*) "puzzle-solving" of a "normal" process with the set of title events denoted by this adjective, which are described as "gestalt switches" using the analogy of the duck-rabbit illusion. The term "paradigm shift" was coined in that book on these sorts of "revolutions" by Thomas Kuhn. For 10 points, give this adjective which denotes a method" which tests theories via experimentation.
tossups.answer: scientific [accept The Scientific Image or scientific realism or The Structure of Scientific Revolutions or scientific method]

tossups.question: This building's walls oddly contain portions of Roman sarcophagi that depict a boar hunt and men harvesting wine. Two hunting dogs bark at the feet of Jacob and Esau in a highly-praised relief on this building's exterior. It's not a tower, but eight images of theological and cardinal virtues were created in 1302 by Andrea Pisano as part of one portion of this building. The Bargello ("bar-JEL-loh") contains two contrasting versions of the sacrifice of (*) Isaac that served as models for another portion of this building. Jacopo Della Quercia ("KWARE-chuh") participated in a 1401 competition hosted by the Cloth Guild to design its east doors, whose winner contains 10 gilded panels depicting scenes from the Old and New Testaments. For 10 points, Lorenzo Ghiberti’s Gates of Paradise is a part of what Florentine building, created for a specific sacrament?
tossups.answer: Florentine Baptistery [or Florence Baptistery, or Baptistery of St. John, or Battistero di San Giovanni]

tossups.question: This substance titles a poem which calls Jesus the "starved man hung upon the cross" and describes it as "dark as the world of man" after the Blitz. Another poem titled for this substance says "Not one would mind, neither bird nor tree / If mankind perished utterly". In a third poem, this non-electric substance arrives near Himavant after a cock crows "Co co rico" in mountains where "there is not even silence". In a story, a poem titled for this substance is read to Mrs. McClellan by a (*) house before it catches fire on August 5, 2026. This substance titles the best-known poem of Sara Teasdale, which inspired a story set after a nuclear apocalypse by Ray Bradbury, titled for "soft" ones. For 10 points, T. S. Eliot's The Waste Land says that April breeds "dull roots" with what wet substance?
tossups.answer: rain [accept "Still Falls the Rain" or "There Will Come Soft Rains"; prompt on water or showers or precipitation] (The first clue is from Edith Sitwell's "Still Falls the Rain.")

bonuses.leadin: This city's Ben Ezra Synagogue was likely destroyed on the orders of al-Hakim. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city, which grew out of the Byzantine fortress of Babylon and eventually became Cairo under the Fatimids. Its name derives from a loose Arabic transliteration of the Latin word for "encampment".

This caliph sent the general Amr ibn al-'As to capture that fortress at Babylon, whereupon he founded Fustat. This caliph, who succeeded Abu Bakr and preceded Uthman, was given the title al-Farooq by Muhammad.
Fustat absorbed the neighboring suburb of al-Aksar under this caliphate, which succeeded the Umayyads and had its capital at Baghdad.

bonuses.leadin: This musician lends his name to the ES-150 Gibson model and its iconic single-bar pickup, which he played on songs like "Solo Flight". For 10 points each:
parts: Name this musician who is often called the "father of jazz guitar".
Christian popularized the guitar as part of this musician's band, which he joined two years after it gave the first-ever live jazz concert at Carnegie Hall in 1938.
Charlie Christian may have coined the term for this style of jazz, whose name comes from nonsense words used in scat singing. Its other exemplars include Charlie Parker.

bonuses.leadin: Hester slits her daughter's throat in an allusion to this Greek play in Marina Carr's drama By the Bog of Cats. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Creon (The son is Haemon, from Antigone.)
parts: Name this Euripedes play whose title woman murders her own children and revels in the misery of her husband, the Argonaut Jason.
Medea is particularly hurt by Jasons's desire to marry this woman, so she sends her a poisoned golden peplos garment which consumes her limbs like fire.

Glauce's father, a king with this name, burns to death trying to save Glauce from the poison. In another Greek play, the son of a king of this name kills himself in a cave, lamenting over the death of his betrothed.

bonuses.leadin: This technique provides complementary information to Raman spectroscopy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this technique that probes molecular vibrational modes using light of wavelength slightly longer than visible light.
This functional group is identified in IR spectroscopy by a very broad peak around 3200 to 3500 inverse centimeters.
Polyatomic molecules can undergo 6 different types of vibrational motion -- 2 stretching modes and 4 bending modes. Name any 3 of the 4 types of bending modes.

bonuses.leadin: Twelve of these beings protect Yakushi Nyorai, the Buddha of medicine. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: yakshas [or yakkhas; or yasha; or yakusha; accept yakshis, yakshinis, or yakkhinis; accept jakis]
wealth [or prosperity; accept answers that refer to being rich or prosperous or making money; prompt on artha]
parts: Name these figures that, in Buddhism, are interpreted as guardian spirits of nature. The Four Heavenly Kings are often depicted crushing evil versions of these beings under their feet.

The king of the yakshas, named Kubera ("koo-BARE-uh") or Vaisravana ("vaish-RUH-vuh-nuh") depending on religion, is often considered a god of this property. Many Hindus sweep their houses and perform Lakshmi Puja in hopes of acquiring this property.
This Hindu epic includes several references to the yaksha kingdom and features an expedition there by its protagonists, the Pandavas ("PAHN-duh-vuhs").

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these Civil War era songs with further impact on US politics:
answers_sanitized: "Nelly Bly" [or Nellie Bly; prompt on partial answer]
parts: This song by Julia Ward Howe, which begins "My eyes hath seen the glory," served as a rallying cry for abolitionists during the war.

This song, whose title alludes to Sherman's March to the Sea, was played to honor many veterans at political nominations. A performance of it by a Northern band at the 1924 DNC pissed off KKK members among the Southern delegation.

The title character of this Stephen Foster tune, popular during the era, was later chosen by editor George Madden as the pen name for a journalist who wrote the article "A Plucky Woman" for the Pittsburgh Dispatch.

bonuses.leadin: This distribution is commonly used in simulations when the most probable outcome is known, but not much else is known about the distribution. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this distribution whose mean is the sum of the lower bound, the mode, and the upper bound divided by 3.
Since the triangular distribution is a continuous distribution, this is the probability that a random variable exactly (emphasize) equals the mode.

The average of two independent and identical variables following this distribution follows a triangular distribution. The variance of this distribution equals one-twelfth times the square of the difference between the lower and upper bounds.

bonuses.leadin: This sociologist explored the "leisure gap" between men and women in an analysis of the double burden of employed mothers. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: C. Wright Mills [or Charles Wright Mills]
parts: Name this author of The Second Shift who posited that workers often must manage their feelings while working in The Managed Heart.

Hochschild's study of flight attendants led her to posit a type of "labor" in which workers control these things. Schachter created a two-factor theory of these phenomena, which include shame and fear.
Many of Hochschild's works, such as The Managed Heart, link "private troubles" and "public issues," a tradition developed by this sociologist in The Sociological Imagination.

bonuses.leadin: A sequel to this story, "The Discourager of Hesitancy", begins with five travelers visiting a kingdom to discover what happened to the lover in this story. For 10 points each:
parts: A king sets his daughter's lover to choose between two doors, behind which lies either death or a woman, in what short story by Frank R. Stockton?
Upon finding the tiger Sher Khan asleep, Mowgli and Akela order a stampede of wolves to kill him in a story from this Rudyard Kipling collection.
In this title story of a collection by Julio Cortázar ("core-TAH-sar"), the young girl Isabel spends her summer living in a country house inhabited by an unrestrained tiger, which she never sees.

bonuses.leadin: This instrument plays a jaunty tune in the "Humor" movement of William Grant Still's "Afro-American" Symphony. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Ferde Grofé [or Ferdinand Rudolph von Grofé]
Perpetual Motion [do not accept or prompt on "perpetuum mobile"]
parts: Name this string instrument with a circular frame common in bluegrass music. It was played by Earl Scruggs, who developed a plucking style for it.
This Franco-American composer of the Grand Canyon Suite included a part for tenor banjo in his orchestration of Rhapsody in Blue.

Béla Fleck and Edgar Meyer won a Grammy for an album with this title that includes 20 pieces of classical music arranged for banjo. A piece from the Suzuki curriculum with this English title consists of 32 measures of straight eighth notes.

bonuses.leadin: Aref resists his parents' plans to emigrate to attend grad school in Ann Arbor in Naomi Shihab Nye's book titled for the "turtle of" this country. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Oman [or Sultanate of Oman; or Salṭanat 'Umān; accept The Turtle of Oman]
the Moon [or Luna; accept A Trip to the Moon]
oranges [accept Bitter Orange or A Clockwork Orange or Naranjah]
parts: Name this home country of Jokha al-Harthi, who won the 2019 Booker International Prize for her novel Celestial Bodies.
In the original Arabic, Celestial Bodies is titled for al-Qamar, which is this specific body. A society of Civil War enthusiasts builds a giant cannon to voyage to this body in a Jules Verne novel.

Al-Harthi's book titled for a "bitter" one of these objects will be published in English in 2021. Another novel titled for these objects is named for the manuscript of F. Alexander, whose wife is violated by an ultra-violent gang.

bonuses.leadin: In molecular dynamics, or MD, "fields" named for this quantity simulate interactions between molecules. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: QM/MM methods [or quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics methods]
parts: Name this quantity which, for two point charges, varies with the inverse square of distance by Coulomb's law.

When doing MD simulations in the canonical ensemble, one must use a velocity rescaling algorithm based on this theorem to control the temperature. This theorem states that each quadratic degree of freedom contributes one-half kT to the system’s energy.

Karplus, Levitt, and Warshel won a Nobel for developing this class of so-called "hybrid" methods for MD simulations. They combine accurate-but-computationally-costly quantum calculations with less-accurate-but-simple classical force fields.

bonuses.leadin: Adolf Jensen postulated the notion of the Dema Deity after visiting this archipelago, whose capital is Ambon. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Maluku Islands [or Moluccas; prompt on Spice Islands]
parts: Name this Indonesian archipelago whose people celebrate the myth of Hainuwele ("hai-noo-way-lay"). Nearly half a million people were displaced by Christian-Muslim sectarian conflict on these islands in the 1990s.
According to legend, a hunter discovered Hainuwele in the spot where he had planted this fruit. The Philippines is one of the world's largest exporters of copra, a dried product made from this fruit.
Many Moluccans speak a creole of this language. A peninsula with the same name is separated from Sumatra by the Strait of Malacca.

bonuses.leadin: An object of this name was washed in the yearly Plynteria and was said to have fallen from the sky in Athens. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Palladium [or Palladion; do not accept or prompt on "Pallas"]
Erechtheum [or Erechtheion] (It is named for Erechtheus.)
parts: Give the name of that cult statue of Athena. Troy was legendarily protected by a wooden statue of the same name, which was made by Athena to depict a companion whose name she took as an epithet.

The Palladion was housed in this temple which was dedicated to both Athena and Poseidon and, like the Parthenon, was built under Pericles' leadership. It is named for a king of Athens who was identified with Poseidon.
Near the Erechtheum was a shrine to this Greek god, who used an axe to split open Zeus's head so Athena could be born. He serves as the gods' blacksmith.

bonuses.leadin: Arno Mayer argued that a system of this name "persisted" in controlling European diplomacy up through World War I. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Ancien Régime [prompt on Old Regime or Former Regime by saying "we want the French term"]
parts: Give this two-word term originally used to refer to the system of government in France from the 15th through 18th centuries.
The Ancien Régime is traditionally regarded to have ended with the sociopolitical upheaval of this 10-year long event, which began with the issuing of the "Declaration of the Rights of Man".

This politician condemned the violence of radicals during the French Revolution in his definitive 10-volume history of it. A mob destroyed this president's house after he refused a prisoner exchange of Louis Blanqui ("blon-KEY") for Georges Darboy ("zhorzh dar-BOY").

bonuses.leadin: Despite these diseases having similar prevalence and severity, many studies have observed a large gap in research funding between them. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: cystic fibrosis or CF AND sickle-cell anemia or sickle-cell disease
hydroxyurea [or hydroxycarbamide; accept Hydrea or Droxia]
parts: Name these two genetic disorders. One, found mainly in white individuals, is caused by the delta-F-508 mutation, while the other, mostly found in black individuals, is caused by the E6V mutation.
Both diseases are inherited in this fashion, meaning the gene is not on a sex chromosome, and the phenotype only emerges if both alleles are mutant.
There are many drugs available for cystic fibrosis, but until recently, this drug approved by the FDA in 1967 was the only drug available for sickle-cell anemia.

bonuses.leadin: The biography of this artist by his granddaughter Marina describes him as creating a "virus" within his family through his abuses of family members and women. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Cubist whose depictions of the female form include Les demoiselles d'Avignon ("luh deh-mwah-ZELL dah-veen-YOHN").
In particular, Picasso's relationship with this photographer has been scrutinized, suggesting a new interpretation of his depiction of her in The Weeping Woman.

Critics have also fixated on Picasso’s depiction of his own penis on the face of Marie-Thérèse Walter in this painting. Shortly after Steve Wynn bought this painting, he destroyed $50 million of its value by accidentally sticking his elbow through the canvas while showing it off to friends.

bonuses.leadin: In Côte d'Ivoire, this crop is grated, fermented, and steamed in a dish called attiéké. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: fufu [or foofoo, or fufuo, or foufou]
okra [or ochro, or Abelmoschus esculentus; accept ladies' fingers]
parts: Name this staple crop in West African cuisine that is made into a paste in the dish eba. This tuber, which is native to the Amazon and often dried to make tapioca, can't be eaten raw since it contains cyanide.
This West African dish is prepared by mixing and pounding equal portions of cassava and plantain flour. It is commonly served with groundnut or palm nut soup.
Fufu can also be made with the edible seed pods of this green plant. It's also used in many dishes from the US South, such as gumbo and a popcorn-sized snack made by frying it.

bonuses.leadin: An author with this surname collected poetry like "The Lights at Carney's Point" in her first book, Violets and Other Tales. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Dunbar [accept Paul Laurence Dunbar; accept Alice Moore Dunbar-Nelson]
parts: Give this married surname of Alice, who published poetry in magazines like The Crisis. Her husband with this surname debuted as a poet with his collection Oak and Ivy.
Alice Dunbar's husband Paul wrote this poem, which concludes "But let the world dream otherwise". Its title object "hides our cheeks and shades our eyes."
Paul Dunbar's poem "Sympathy" provided the title for this author's autobiography I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings. She also wrote "On the Pulse of Morning".

bonuses.leadin: Prince Alfred von Windischgrätz ("VIN-dish-gretz") led a brutal crackdown on the Pentecostal Uprising in this city. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Josip Jelačić ("YELL-uh-cheech") [or Count Josip Jelačić von Bužim]
parts: Name this city. Many attendees of a Pan-Slavic congress in this city, which occurred in the same year, were students of its Charles University.

The congress was created in this year, known as the "Spring of Nations" throughout Europe. Elsewhere in the Austrian empire, Magyars launched a rebellion in this year for fair representation in the empire's diet.
This Croatian nobleman helped quash the Magyar rebellion in order to gain favor for his people with Austria. He issued a proclamation that abolished serfdom in Croatia.
